content.body: Hello everyone
Wanted to ask one question that has been troubling me for a while?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Wanted to ask one question that has been troubling me for a while?

content.body: Back in the day, W3C had three divisions of the DOM spec. One was core DOM, the other was HTML DOM and the third was XML DOM. But when I go to the WHATWG spec, there is no mention of this distinction. My point is, that is this distinction still made in the specs of the DOM or can we now safely assume that there is no such distinction and that there is just one DOM spec.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Back in the day, W3C had three divisions of the DOM spec. One was core DOM, the other was HTML DOM and the third was XML DOM. But when I go to the WHATWG spec, there is no mention of this distinction. My point is, that is this distinction still made in the specs of the DOM or can we now safely assume that there is no such distinction and that there is just one DOM spec.

content.body: The Freelancer: there's no XML DOM vs HTML DOM anymore, though the behavior of some APIs differ between HTML and XML. It's just the DOM spec, and some things that were previously in the "HTML DOM" spec is now in the HTML spec
content.formatted_body: The Freelancer: there's no XML DOM vs HTML DOM anymore, though the behavior of some APIs differ between HTML and XML. It's just the DOM spec, and some things that were previously in the "HTML DOM" spec is now in the HTML spec

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: The Freelancer: there's no XML DOM vs HTML DOM anymore, though the behavior of some APIs differ between HTML and XML. It's just the DOM spec, and some things that were previously in the "HTML DOM" spec is now in the HTML spec

The Freelancer: there's no XML DOM vs HTML DOM anymore, though the behavior of some APIs differ between HTML and XML. It's just the DOM spec, and some things that were previously in the "HTML DOM" spec is now in the HTML spec

content.body: e.g. `createElement` and `createCDATASection`

zcorpan: So if some other vendor, or let's say a library author for another language such as Python, wants to implement the DOM, they have to go through the WHATWG spec. Is that right? But then how would that person be able to distinguish between what's really meant for HTML, what's meant for XML, and what's meant for both. I hope you get my point.
content.formatted_body: zcorpan: So if some other vendor, or let's say a library author for another language such as Python, wants to implement the DOM, they have to go through the WHATWG spec. Is that right? But then how would that person be able to distinguish between what's really meant for HTML, what's meant for XML, and what's meant for both. I hope you get my point.

Is that right? But then how would that person be able to distinguish between what's really meant for HTML, what's meant for XML, and what's meant for both. I hope you get my point.

zcorpan: So if some other vendor, or let's say a library author for another language such as Python, wants to implement the DOM, they have to go through the WHATWG spec. Is that right? But then how would that person be able to distinguish between what's really meant for HTML, what's meant for XML, and what's meant for both. I hope you get my point.

content.body: The Freelancer: if they don't support HTML, then they can no-op the parts that branch off of an HTML check
content.formatted_body: The Freelancer: if they don't support HTML, then they can no-op the parts that branch off of an HTML check

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: The Freelancer: if they don't support HTML, then they can no-op the parts that branch off of an HTML check
The Freelancer: if they don't support HTML, then they can no-op the parts that branch off of an HTML check

content.body: Sorry, but I didn't get that.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Sorry, but I didn't get that.

content.body: Sorry, jargon :) no-op means no operation, meaning code that does nothing (or no code)
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Sorry, jargon :) no-op means no operation, meaning code that does nothing (or no code)

content.body: For example, when implementing https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-document-createelement , if "this" can never be an HTML document (because HTML is not supported), then you can skip step 2
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: For example, when implementing https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-document-createelement , if "this" can never be an HTML document (because HTML is not supported), then you can skip step 2

content.body: Ok, so that means that any person wanting to implement the DOM for HTML or non-HTML documents has to nonetheless go through the whole document filtering out what he/she really needs?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Ok, so that means that any person wanting to implement the DOM for HTML or non-HTML documents has to nonetheless go through the whole document filtering out what he/she really needs?

content.body: Am I right?
yes
One more thing, sorry to disturb you again and again, what was the motivation behind unifying these three DOM specifications (i.e. HTML DOM, XML DOM, and Core DOM)?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: One more thing, sorry to disturb you again and again, what was the motivation behind unifying these three DOM specifications (i.e. HTML DOM, XML DOM, and Core DOM)?

content.body: Browser engines is the primary implementer for web specs, and they have a single implementation of the DOM, not 3
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Browser engines is the primary implementer for web specs, and they have a single implementation of the DOM, not 3

content.body: It's easier to have a well-defined easy-to-implement spec if the behavior of an API is in one algorithm, instead of spread out across different documents
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: It's easier to have a well-defined easy-to-implement spec if the behavior of an API is in one algorithm, instead of spread out across different documents

content.body: That sounds relatable :)
One last thing if you don't mind. May I?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: One last thing if you don't mind. May I?

content.body: don't ask to ask, just ask :)
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: don't ask to ask, just ask :)

content.body: Thanks a lot. I don't find the style property in the WHATWG DOM standard. It's instead in the HTML standard. Why is this so? I guess that the style JavaScript property is also part of the DOM, then why does it get its place in the WHATWG HTML standard?
